block.p: ''Polar Thinking on the Antarctic'' by Deborah Shapley (Op-Ed, Oct. 17) would have us believe that a treaty allowing minerals development in Antarctica is the best way to protect this fragile environment.

Unfortunately, the facts and the more than 150 environmental organizations opposed to the plan do not support Ms. Shapley's arguments. No gains to international law can be worth the damage that can and will be done if nations agree to exploit Antarctica. The true scientific value of the Antarctic is its role as a global laboratory free of local contaminants. With the seriousness and worldwide impact of issues such as ozone depletion and global warming at stake, it is likely that interest in Antarctic science will only increase.

Even scientific operations have had an impact on the Antarctic. In the last year alone four oil spills, including the wreck of the Argentine tanker Bahia Paraiso, carrying 250,000 gallons of oil, have occurred in Antarctica. This is but a taste of the destruction awaiting the continent if development begins on any scale.

Environmental groups such as Greenpeace, as well as the nations opposing the minerals treaty - Australia, France, Belgium, Italy and India - have more in mind than just disrupting talks and adding to diplomatic conflict. Ms. Shapley acknowledges that the minerals treaty is no better than a compromise between industry and preservation. Seeking to preserve the planet's last unspoiled continent calls for more than that; it calls for a truly farsighted agree-ment that will protect Antarctica for science and for the generations to come. PAUL BOGART Coordinator Greenpeace Antarctic Campaign Washington, Oct. 18, 1989
